facts.text: Parties are Jains from Balapur in district of Akola, previous State of Madhya Pradesh. Pedigree: Lal Chand (deceased) married to Samarath Bai (respondent), authorized her to adopt Champalal (appellant, son of Ishwardas).
On September 14, 1944, Lal Chand made a will authorizing wife Samarath Bai to adopt Champalal and made certain dispositions of property.
Lal Chand died on September 26, 1944.
Will registered on December 29, 1944.

On October 20, 1944, appellant applied under s.192 Succession Act to First Additional District Judge, Akola for appointment of Curator (Misc. Judl. No. 3 of 1944). Notices issued to respondent and daughters.
On January 10, 1945, arbitration agreement entered into between appellant and respondent.
On January 16, 1945, both parties applied for stay of proceedings in Misc. Judl. No. 3/1944; case adjourned to March 28, 1945, then to June 18, 1945.
On June 18, 1945, arbitrators applied for extension of time for four months; opposed by appellant; court granted three months on July 26, 1946.
Award made on October 18, 1946.
On October 21, 1946, award filed by arbitrators in court of First Additional District Judge; notice given to parties by registered post.
On October 30, 1946, court gave parties ten days for objections.
On November 15, 1946, appellant filed objections to award.
On January 31, 1947, respondent applied for judgment in terms of award and decree.
Award unregistered; handed to Mithulal (attorney of two arbitrators) for registration.
On February 7, 1947, Mithulal presented award for registration; returned as not accompanied by list and particulars of property.
On February 15, 1947, list and particulars signed by Mithulal supplied; award re-presented.
On March 26, 1947, Sub-Registrar registered qua two arbitrators, refused qua third (Bhogilal); later registered fully under Registrar's orders.
Award re-filed in court on July 21, 1948.
On August 14, 1948, court ordered separation of proceedings under Succession Act and Arbitration Act; latter registered as suit.
On August 30, 1948, court ordered proper application under High Court Rules.
On September 15, 1948, application under s.14(2) Arbitration Act filed.
On October 14, 1948, appellant filed application to set aside award raising objections.
On November 22, 1949, First Additional District Judge passed judgment and decree in terms of award (Civil Suit No. 12-A of 1948).
Appeal to Nagpur High Court (Misc. Appeal No. 164 of 1949) dismissed on February 19, 1954.

High Court findings: Application under s.14(2) within time; no objection to two awards; judge authorised to extend time; no misconduct or illegality proved; appellant got nothing under will except on adoption, not constituted executor.
Appellant not prepared to be adopted, as per evidence and his own ground of appeal in High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether filing of award was within time as no application under s.14 made within time allowed by Limitation Act.
Whether award required registration and was not registered in accordance with law.
Whether First Additional District Judge had jurisdiction to grant extension of time on July 26, 1946.
Whether award in excess of powers under arbitration agreement.
Whether respondent refused to adopt appellant, so decree should follow alternative contingency in award; or court lacked jurisdiction for subsequent events.

petitioner_arguments.text: Filing of award not within time as no application under s.14 within Limitation Act time.
Award required registration; not registered properly as Mithulal lacked authority for list/particulars.
First Additional District Judge had no jurisdiction to extend time.
Arbitrators guilty of misconduct: decided award before hearing parties.
Award in excess of powers: reference invalid as appellant executor; exceeded para 1 of agreement; contrary to law.
Respondent refused adoption; decree per alternative; no jurisdiction for subsequent events.

respondent_arguments.text: Original filing by arbitrators within time; s.14(2) application timely.

court_reasoning.text: Points 1,2,3 without substance: Art.178 applies to parties' applications, not arbitrators' filing; unregistered award can be filed, prohibition only for evidence affecting immovable property; lists not necessary, Mithulal's act immaterial; court had jurisdiction as proper court for applications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Filing by arbitrators on Oct 21, 1946 valid.

court_reasoning.text: No misconduct proved: charge based on after-thought statement; arbitrators sought amicable settlement.
Appellant not executor eo instante but only if adopted; no need to decide executor arbitration bar.
Award not in excess: maintained will gifts/charities; decided consequences of adoption/non-adoption per agreement para 2; time limit implicit; appellant not prepared to be adopted per evidence.
No perversion of succession; award provides for adoption scenario.

holdings.text: Award validly filed, registered, extended; no misconduct; within powers; appellant not adopted due to his refusal.
No substance in points 1-6 raised by appellant.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Arbitration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing filing of award, extension of time, judgment in terms.

statutes_cited.name: Registration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Requirement for registration of award affecting immovable property; filing unregistered award.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Time for applications under Arbitration Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal against High Court order upholding decree in terms of arbitration award, finding all appellant's objections without substance.

key_quotes.text: "In our opinion points No. 1, 2 and 3 are wholly without substance."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The words under the said will the said Champalal shall be the executor of the will after my death if I adopt him during my lifetime or even if my wife adopts him after my death show that the appellant was to become executor after his adoption"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "There is no force in this appeal and it must therefore fail."
key_quotes.speaker: court
